title: Ben Youngs confronts claims England are under-cooked after missed French test
text:

Ben Youngs faced up to World Cup concerns for England last night and claimed: “We’re in exactly the right spot”.

A blank weekend means they arrive at Saturday’s quarter-final showdown against Australia having not played for a fortnight.

World Cup winner Paul Grayson believes that leaves them short of rugby ahead of England’s biggest match since Australia knocked them out of the last tournament four years ago.

But Youngs, England’s senior player, countered: “I certainly don’t feel we’re under-cooked. We’ve had a good run of games, including our pre-season, and I think we’re in exactly the right spot.

(Image: Getty Images)

“The way that we train is with a huge amount of intensity, so I don't believe it will be a factor. And we haven’t had to show a huge amount yet – and that’s a good thing.”

Grayson’s concern is that having played against 14 men for the last hour against Argentina and then lost the France game to Typhoon Hagibis, England face a “giant leap” in intensity against the Wallabies.

“The intensity in World Cup knockout games goes through the roof,” he reasons. “And in this England squad only four players have ever experienced it.”

Youngs is one of those but feels the experience gained, in particular, by the players of Saracens, equips them for the ‘Ashes’ battle to come.

“Those Sarries boys have played some huge fixtures in Europe and are used to big games,” he said. “We’ve done a lot of work on an off the field to make sure we won’t tighten up.

“I think those guys, in the positions that they play, will allow the team to feel relaxed and go out there to play how we play and not feel that tight about it - or let the occasion get to us.”

(Image: Action Images via Reuters)

Youngs refers to Owen Farrell, Jamie George, Maro Itoje, George Kruis and the Vunipola brothers - though Billy Vunipola remains a doubt due to an ankle injury.

England have not played a ‘sudden death’ match for eight years, since they were bundled out of the 2011 World Cup quarter-finals by an unfancied France team.

“They were deemed to be in turmoil,” Youngs recalled. “It was a lesson that you can't read anything into what has happened in the past. It is all about that 80 minutes.

(Image: Getty Images)

“Don't believe your own hype as a side. Just take every day as it comes. It’s not about what happened when you played each other before. It is just about there and then.”

Given that England have beaten Australia in all six matches since Jones took charge, that is valuable advice. They again go into the last-eight as heavy favourites.

‘We have to just make sure that we keep level-headed about it and don’t rely on what has happened before, thinking that will be enough," Youngs added. "Because it won’t be."
description: Scrum-half responds to Mirror columnist Paul Grayson's fear that England are worryingly short of game time heading into World Cup quarter-final against Australia
